Q6-direction_total.name: Q6-1
Q6-direction_total.question: What is the direction of the net transport due to all contributions combined (total flux)?

options.c: depends on the distance from the shore

feedback.correct: Correct, the total measured velocity moments are negative everywhere in the profile.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Which symbols indicate the total measured third odd and fourth odd velocity moments and what is their sign?

Q6-direction_mean.name: Q6-2
Q6-direction_mean.question: What is the direction of the transport by the calculated undertow or return flow (mean flux)?

options.c: depends on the distance from the shore

feedback.correct: Correct, the dash-dot line represents this mean flux.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Which line represents the undertow or return flow?

Q6-direction_skewness.name: Q6-3
Q6-direction_skewness.question: What is the direction of the transport by skewness (short-wave flux)?

options.c: depends on the distance from the shore

feedback.correct: Correct, the diamonds indicate the short-wave contribution and are positive in the entire profile
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Which symbols indicate the short-wave contribution to the third and fourth odd velocity moments and what is their sign?

Q6-direction_long.name: Q6-4
Q6-direction_long.question: What is the direction of the transport by long waves (long-wave flux)?

options.c: depends on the distance from the shore

feedback.correct: Correct. Can you explain the direction of the transport due to long waves from the correlation between the bound long waves and the wave group? Have look at Figure 7.20 and read Section 5.8.2 in the textbook.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Have a look at the dashed line. What is the sign of this line in the shoaling zone and in the (inner) surf zone?

Q6-breakpoint_position.name: Q6-5
Q6-breakpoint_position.question: Make an estimate for the seaward limit of the surf zone (the position of the breakpoint). How far is the breakpoint from the shoreline (approximately)? Choose the answer that is most likely.

feedback.correct: Correct. We can estimate this from the following facts. First, both the onshore directed short-wave term and the offshore directed long-wave term increase when the waves are shoaling until point of breaking. Based on this you may guess a width of 12.5 to 13 m. Now remember that we are dealing with irregular waves and that we are after the point of initial breaking (where the highest waves break). This will thus be a bit further seaward, at say 15 m from the waterline. Second, the undertow contribution is more or less restricted to the surf zone (with nonzero velocties also outside and the maximum inside the surf zone). That the maximum at around 12 m can partly be attributed to a delay in the conversion of organized wave energy into turbulent motion (you will learn more about this in the B module).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. What do you know of the direction of each of the mean, short-wave and long-wave transport contributions in the surf zone and shoaling zone? Note also that we consider the shoreline to be at x = 40 m. How far seaward from that point is the breakpoint?

Q6-conditions_fig721.name: Q6-6
Q6-conditions_fig721.question: For which conditions is Figure 7.21 representative?

feedback.correct: Correct, for storm conditions the offshore flux due to (mainly) undertow is dominant transport mechanism over the onshore flux due to waves, resulting in an offshore transport in the surf zone.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. For calm conditions the onshore flux due to waves will be dominant over the offshore transport by (mainly) undertow. What might a similar figure look like for calm conditions?

Q6-morphological_response.name: Q6-7
Q6-morphological_response.question: What morphological response can be expected?

feedback.correct: Correct, during a storm sediment will be transported in offshore direction. Sediment will be eroded from the upper parts of the profile where the transport increases in seaward direction. In the lower part of the profile the seaward transport decreases again in seaward direction, leading to deposition. Hence, right after a storm, the profile is flatter and more dissipative than before the storm.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Remember that the net offshore transport implies that sediment will be moved to deeper portion in the profile.

Q6-unit_a.name: Q6-8
Q6-unit_a.question: The unit of transport used in the plot is kg/m/s. How can this be understood?

options.a: We are considering sediment mass flux c*u integrated over depth hence the unit is [kg/m^3*m/s*m].
options.b: We are considering sediment mass flux c*u integrated over the surf zone hence the unit is [kg/m^3*m/s*m].
options.c: We are considering sediment mass flux c*u per meter coastline length hence the unit is [kg/m^3*m/s*m].

feedback.correct: Correct, the measured concentrations are in kg/m^3, the velocities in m/s and the sediment flux c*u is integrated over the bottom 15 cm.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect, there is no integration over the surf zone or in alongshore direction.

Q6-unit_b.name: Q6-8a
Q6-unit_b.question: In order to obtain the rate of bed change dz/dt, we must multiply dQ/dx with one or more multiplication factors. Which?

options.b: A factor 1/rho with rho the density in [kg/m^3]
options.d: The factor 1/p with p the porosity
options.e: The factor 1/(1-p) with p the porosity

feedback.correct: Correct, Eq. 1.1 in the book translates to dz/dt=-dS/dx with z positive upwards and S [m^3/m/s] positive in positive x-direction and including the effect of pores. This formula stresses that we have defined positive gradients to cause negative bed change or erosion and explains the need of multiplication with -1. Further S is related to Q as: S=Q/rho/(1-p), so we must multiple with 1/rho and 1/(1-p).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. It may help to look up Eq.(1.1) in Section 1.5.2 of the book and read up on Section 6.2.2.

Q6-width_surf_zone.name: Q6-9
Q6-width_surf_zone.question: How wide is the surf zone approximately? Give your answer in meters, rounded to the nearest multiple of 5.

feedback.correct: Correct. You could now also compute the average profile slope in the surf zone to check the above statement that this is a quite steep profile.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Measure the approximate distance from the waterline to the breakpoint. Note that the position of the breakpoint is indicated in the bathymetry panel with a grey dashed vertical line.

Q6-direction_waves_undertow.name: Q6-10
Q6-direction_waves_undertow.question: What is the direction of transport due to waves? And due to undertow?

feedback.correct: Correct, the transport due to waves is onshore directed and first increases when the waves approach the shore and then decreases to zero at the waterline. The mean transport, due to undertow, is offshore directed.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Find the line in the second panel representing the oscillatory transport. What is its sign? What about the mean transport?

Q6-onshore_transport_waves.name: Q6-11
Q6-onshore_transport_waves.question: Where do we see onshore transport due to waves (for which values of h/h_b)?

options.a: In the shoaling zone and surf zone (so the entire range of h/h_b)

feedback.correct: Correct, we see that the transport due to waves increases in the shoaling zone to a maximum in the surf zone and then decreases to zero at the water line. Can you explain this?
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Consider the yellow line and identify the shoaling zone and surf zone.

Q6-offshore_transport_undertow.name: Q6-12
Q6-offshore_transport_undertow.question: Where do we see offshore transport due to undertow (for which values of h/h_b)?

options.a: In the shoaling zone and surf zone (the entire range of h/h_b)
options.b: Mainly in the shoaling zone only (h/h_b > 1)
options.c: Mainly in the surf zone (h/h_b < 1), but also a bit outside

feedback.correct: Correct, the offshore transport due to undertow is (more or less) restricted to the surf zone
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Is there an undertow in the shoaling zone?

Q6-direction_total_high_energy.name: Q6-13
Q6-direction_total_high_energy.question: For these high-energy conditions, how does the direction of the total transport vary with h/h_b?

options.a: Onshore for h/h_b < 1, offshore for h/h_b > 1
options.b: Offshore for h/h_b < 1, onshore for h/h_b > 1
options.c: Onshore for h/h_b < 0.6, offshore for h/h_b > 0.6
options.d: Offshore for h/h_b < 0.6, onshore for h/h_b > 0.6
options.e: Onshore for h/h_b < 0.75, offshore for h/h_b > 0.75
options.f: Offshore for h/h_b < 0.75, onshore for h/h_b > 0.75

feedback.correct: Correct. Under high-energy condition the shape function predicts an onshore transport in the shoaling zone and the outer part of the surf zone and an offshore transport in the inner part of the surf zone.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Select the total surf/shoaling transport (grey line). For which h/h_b does this transport reverse direction?

Q6-compare_Tinker_book.name: Q6-14
Q6-compare_Tinker_book.question: Compare the above findings for Sennen Cove with Figure 7.21 from the book. This figure also represents storm conditions. Which transport component is much larger according to Tinker's shape functions in comparison to Figure 7.21?

options.a: The offshore transport due to undertow in the surf zone
options.b: The onshore transport due to waves in the shoaling zone
options.c: The onshore transport due to waves in the surf zone
options.d: The offshore transport due to undertow in the shoaling zone

feedback.correct: Correct. Note that this leads to a net onshore transport in the shoaling zone and also in the outer part of the surf zone. But keep in mind that under high-energy conditions data beyond the breakpoint were limited, which introduces uncertainty in the shape functions.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Compare the oscillatory transports and the total transports of Figure 7.21 and Sennen Cove.

Q6-morphological_response_surf.name: Q6-15
Q6-morphological_response_surf.question: What morphological response can be expected? First focus on the surf zone where the changes are largest.

feedback.correct: Correct, in that sense this situation is comparable with the type of conditions of figure 7.21. Check the transport gradients of the total transport in the surf zone. These point towards erosion closer to the shore and accretion further from the shore (but still in the surf zone).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Compare this situation to the situation of Q6. Also, check the transport gradients of the total transport line and draw conclusions about the bed changes to be expected (in which zones do you expect sedimentation and erosion, where are the locations of maximum erosion and sedimentation?

Q6-morphological_response_shoal.name: Q6-16
Q6-morphological_response_shoal.question: Now look at the shoaling zone and outer part of the surf zone. Based on the shape functions, what would the morphodynamic response be here?

options.a: Erosion seaward of the breakpoint and erosion landward of it.
options.b: Sedimentation seaward of the breakpoint and sedimentation landward of it.
options.c: Erosion seaward of the breakpoint and sedimentation landward of it.
options.d: Sedimentation seaward of the breakpoint and erosion landward of it.

feedback.correct: Correct. Going in onshore direction, the onshore directed total transport slowly increases (positive gradient) until slightly offshore of the breakpoint and then starts to decrease. This implies first erosion and then accretion. You can conclude this also from the plot with the transport gradients.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Select the total surf/zone transport and consider the transport gradients in the direction of the positive transport.

Q6-width_surf_zone2.name: Q6-17
Q6-width_surf_zone2.question: How wide is the surf zone approximately? Give your answer in meters, rounded to the nearest multiple of 5.

feedback.correct: Correct. This is a much narrower surf zone than for the high-energy conditions.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Measure the approximate distance from the waterline to the breakpoint. Note that the position of the breakpoint is indicated in the bathymetry panel with a grey dashed vertical line.

Q6-transport_direction_waves_undertow.name: Q6-18
Q6-transport_direction_waves_undertow.question: What is the direction of transport due to waves? And due to undertow?

options.a: onshore in the shoaling zone and surf zone, offshore in the surf zone
options.b: onshore in the shoaling zone, offshore in the surf zone
options.c: offshore in the shoaling zone and surf zone, onshore in the surf zone
options.d: onshore in the shoaling zone, offshore in the surf zone

feedback.correct: Correct. Also check the position of the offshore and onshore maximum. The onshore maximum is closer to the breakpoint and the offshore maximum closer to the shore.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Find the lines in the second panel representing the mean and oscillatory transport.

Q6-difference_high_low_energy.name: Q6-19
Q6-difference_high_low_energy.question: The correct answer to the previous question is the same for low-energy and high-energy conditions. What then is different for lower-energy conditions as compared to higher-energy conditions?

options.a: The mean and oscillatory transport magnitudes are much lower
options.b: The oscillatory transport magnitude is much lower, the mean transport is comparable in magnitude
options.c: The transport is confined to a narrower zone
options.d: The total transport now is offshore directed in surf zone and shoaling zone
options.e: The total transport now is onshore directed in surf zone and shoaling zone
options.f: The total transport is now maximum just inside the surf zone
options.g: The total transport is now maximum just outside the surf zone

feedback.correct: Correct, we see that the total transport is now dominated by the onshore oscillatory transport, which overshadows the offshore directed mean transport. The smaller wave heights lead to lower transport rates and a narrower surf zone.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Consider the three components in the surf/shoaling zone: mean, oscillatory and total. Vary h_b to see what the effect is.

Q6-morphodynamic_response_transport_maxi.name: Q6-20
Q6-morphodynamic_response_transport_maxi.question: We have seen that the transports are onshore and the transport maximum is found just inside the surf zone. What is the expected morphodynamic response?

options.a: sedimentation shoreward of the transport maximum
options.b: erosion shoreward of the transport maximum
options.c: sedimentation seaward of the transport maximum
options.d: erosion seaward of the transport maximum

feedback.correct: Correct, the smaller waves restore the profile by bringing sediment onshore. This can be verified from the plot of the transport gradients, which shows positive gradients seaward of the transport maximum (leading to erosion) and negative gradients shoreward of the transport maximum (leading to accretion). This combination of transports results in a steepening of the profile.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Remember that the smaller waves can restore a profile after a storm. Check also the plot with transport gradients.

Q6-onshore_equals_offshore.name: Q6-21
Q6-onshore_equals_offshore.question: Consider the total (net) transport. For which value of h_b is the onshore transport peak equal in magnitude as the offshore transport peak?

feedback.correct: Correct. Note that an h_b of 1.7 m represents an offshore significant wave height of around 0.8 m
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Study the total surf/shoal transport pattern for all of the above h_b values.

Q6-22.name: Q6-22
Q6-22.question: What differences do you observe between the UK and the Dutch profiles?

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

Q6-23.question: What similarities do you observe between the UK and the Dutch profiles?

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...

feedback.correct: Correct, ...
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ...
